author: vors
body:
<!-- PR checklist -->
- [ ] Resolves issue #xyz.
- [x] Code is up-to-date with `master`.
- [ ] Add tests that fail without your changes.
- [x] Update all relevant [documentation](../docs).

<!-- Provide more details about the PR below -->

Current README.md was handful, when we started create documentation as a guidelines for the team.
Now, when we are approaching release date, team-member has a pretty good understanding of the process and we should clean-up this doc.

cc @HemantMahawar (original author)
@jianyunt @hiteshraigandhi

comments.author: vors
comments.body: Hemant is on vacation, reassigning review to @hiteshraigandhi

comments.author: hiteshraigandhi
comments.body: I think we should still have a readme.md which explains what this folder is for.

comments.author: vors
comments.body:
I find the folder pretty self-explanatory.

@hiteshraigandhi what content would you like to see there?

comments.author: hiteshraigandhi
comments.body: This folder contains the governance and contribution guidelines. Refer to [guidelines](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#contributing-to-documentation) for contribution.

comments.author: jianyunt
comments.body:
We can create an index in this readme just like [.Net](https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/tree/master/Documentation) does if we want to keep it.

or

do not need this readme as all files are referenced in the front page readme already and contributing.md.

comments.author: vors
comments.body:
@hiteshraigandhi there is much more, like learning powershell, git, debugging, building.
Essentially, when somebody opens the folder they will see all the topics.

I agree with @jianyunt , let just remove the readme.
TOC would make changing content harder (one more place to fix links).
Folder structure is TOC essentially.

title: Remove docs\README.md
